timeline.bodyText: '<text>'::regproc in PostgreSQL the cast function will try to look up for the function that corresponds to the string literal. For now, I allowed this cast but it just creates a Regproc object with oid and name, should we forbid the text to regproc cast or keep it?
timeline.author: kovrus

timeline.message: wip: Add the pg `regproc` data type.
wip: Add the pg `regproc` data type.
wip: Add the pg `regproc` data type.
wip: Add the pg `regproc` data type.
Use regproc type for correspodning columns in pg_catalog tables.

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't the name here be the function-name instead of the oid as string? We'd need some kind of reverse lookup, right?
timeline.author: mfussenegger

replies.bodyText: yes, but I am not sure how it is possible, PgType#readBinaryValue should know about registered functions then :/
replies.author: kovrus

timeline.author: mfussenegger

replies.bodyText:
It is actually the behaviour postgresql has, when we cast oid to regproc then it becomes a name as well. See (1::regproc)::text
template1=# select 1::regproc, (1::regproc)::text, pg_typeof(1::regproc);
 regproc | text | pg_typeof
---------+------+-----------
 1       | 1    | regproc
replies.author: kovrus

replies.bodyText:
Only for unknown functions:
select 1242::regproc, 1::regproc;
 regproc | regproc
---------+---------
 boolin  | 1
(1 row)

Not sure if this is problematic, given that clients don't send regproc values and that the joins happen on the oid value anyways.
Maybe we add a comment explaining this behavior for now and follow up if it turns out to be necessary for compatiblity reasons.
replies.author: mfussenegger

replies.bodyText: as i see, i'll update the type documentation. It is also the case for casting a string literal to regproc.
replies.author: kovrus

timeline.author: mfussenegger

timeline.message: Add the CrateDB internal `regproc` data type.
Use regproc type for correspodning columns in pg_catalog tables.
